awd_titl_txt: Using Validation Theory to Enhance the Recruitment, Retention and Success of Academically Talented Low-Income STEM Students at a Rural Institution.
awd_abstract_narration:
The Nebraska Wesleyan University (NWU) Departments of Biology, Chemistry, Mathematics and Physics will recruit 14 new students who are both academically talented and have unmet financial need to pursue majors in these disciplines. The program will provide them with scholarships, and academic and social support, including orientation, Archway Seminar, faculty advising and mentoring, tutoring and Supplemental Instruction, career exploration, internships, research projects, cohort housing, and retreat and regular cohort meetings, to enable them to graduate in four years and successfully pursue either graduate education or a career in a STEM field. The project will simultaneously develop a deeper understanding and increased knowledge of the factors that affect the recruitment, retention, graduation, and post-graduation success of talented low-income students entering STEM disciplines, often from small rural schools.

The project includes an in-depth examination of current institutional practices to address the following research questions: 1) How can STEM faculty adjust curricular and pedagogical norms to foster self-efficacy and the development of a science identity in students? 2) From a student perspective, what experiences influence persistence and success in STEM education? The study will contribute to the knowledge regarding the connections between validation, self-efficacy, science identity and culturally responsive pedagogy, and STEM persistence and success, especially in regards to undergraduate students from low-income backgrounds. The results of this inquiry shared with the STEM education community via publications, presentations at professional meetings and conferences, and via the project website and related media. The project's expected impact also includes strengthening recruitment channels that will steer academically talented, financially needy students from many remote rural high schools to STEM careers; spurring economic growth by building a larger, better-prepared STEM workforce for area employers; and strengthening engagement with businesses and professional alumni.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
``Using Validation Theory to Enhance the Recruitment, Retention and Success of Academically Talented Low-Income STEM Students at a Rural Institution`` (NSF Award #1643499) allowed Nebraska Wesleyan University to provide scholarships to fourteen academically talented and financially needy incoming students declaring STEM majors (hereinafter, ``STEM Scholars``). The goals stated in the proposal included supporting students toward graduation with a STEM degree, securing STEM-related employment or admission to graduate study, and the incorporation of high-impact practices across the institution. These practices were identified through qualitative analysis of student interviews conducted several times over the course of their academic career, which provided insight into the concerns and struggles of the STEM Scholars and painted a picture of their evolving needs. Immediately following graduation of the fourteen STEM Scholars, eight Scholars found employment, three were accepted to graduate study, and three took a gap year to prepare for graduate study.

Brief overviews of the practices and events deemed highest-impact are provided below. Many of these practices are now incorporated in a weekly meeting of STEM-interested students called ``STEM Seminar``, which serves as a convenient organizational hub.

Validation Theory

In ``Validating Culturally Diverse Students: Toward a New Model of Learning and Student Development``, Rendon defines validation as ``an enabling, confirming, and supportive process initiated by in- and out-of-class agents that fosters academic and interpersonal development.`` Validation theory served as a framework for the development of high-impact practices and support structures.

Intrusive Advising

A particularly important concrete element of validation theory is the practice of intrusive advising, which refers to deliberate, proactive relationship building between advisor and student (to contrast with passive advising that engages only in response to student requests). Discipline-specific academic advisors were assigned in the first semester of each STEM Scholar`s academic career. Advisors met with advisees informally (e.g., over coffee or a meal) once each month. In addition, advisees had additional informal contact with advisors at the STEM Seminar meetings, which had the added benefit of serving as a space of interdisciplinarity and collegiality. STEM Scholars revealed in interviews that intrusive advising had a positive impact on their comfort in approaching advisors in times of hardship.

STEM Scholar Retreat

Prior to their first week of classes, STEM Scholars participated in an overnight retreat at a local campground. Scholars were able to meet each other and their advisors in a relaxed, informal setting, which students reported as setting a valuable precedent for their comfort in future interactions. While the overnight retreat model is resource intensive, it is reasonable to suspect that similar benefits can be obtained by shorter, on-campus social events that promote lighthearted engagement among students and faculty.

First-Year Seminar

Nebraska Wesleyan University requires all incoming students to enroll in a first-year seminar. STEM Scholars were all enrolled into a common seminar whose content could be tailored to their needs as STEM majors. The common first-year seminar proved to be a valuable experience to cement the relationships initiated at the retreat, and Scholars felt a sense of belonging to a community of STEM-interested students and faculty within the first weeks of their academic career.

Research Experience

All STEM Scholars participated in original research under the guidance of their academic advisor. Participation in authentic research helped STEM Scholars see themselves as members of the scientific community and had positive impact on the development of their science identity.

Speaker Series and Industry Tours

Each semester, STEM Seminar hosted at least four invited speakers. Speakers represented the rich diversity of science and scientists, further validating Scholars as members of a community. Additionally, Scholars were relieved to hear established scientists speak about their own struggles and uncertainties as students. These personal stories served as a frequent reminder that the struggles Scholars were currently facing are common, expected, and surmountable. Each semester also included an off-campus tour of some local STEM industry. These tours were similarly well-received by Scholars.

Research/Career Workshops

STEM Seminar served as an organizational hub for several workshops related to the pursuit of STEM research experiences and career development. Consensus of students and faculty revealed the following workshops to be most impactful:

  • Goal setting (focused, actionable goals for the semester)
  • Social event (picnic, dinner at faculty home, etc.)
  • Student Research panel (panel of undergraduates speaking about their past research experiences)
  • REU Exploration (familiarizing students with undergraduate research opportunities and how to apply)
  • Graduate study workshop (searching for programs, applying, etc.)
  • Personal Statement workshop (drafting/revising personal statements for research opportunities, graduate study, scholarships, etc.)
  • Resume-building workshop (drafting/revising job application materials)
  • Interview workshop (tips for giving strong interviews, as well as participation in mock interviews)

 


Last Modified: 04/30/2023
Modified by: Austin Mohr
